Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineered Ferroic Superlattices for Science, Technology and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This experimental project is focused on the development of new artificially layered materials with engineered electrical and magnetic properties. With the state of the art deposition facilities in the PI's laboratory, the thickness of the stacked layers in the fabricated materials can be controlled on the atomic scale. The high perfection of the interfaces in these layered structures enables new interactions between the constituent materials to arise, and the result is novel behavior that could be the basis for improved performance in a number of crucial device applications, such as non-volatile computer memories, sensors, actuators and energy harvesters. A suite of cutting edge experimental tools, both in the PI's lab and at user facilities at Brookhaven National Laboratory are being used to probe the physics of the new materials, and build the required understanding for their optimization. The breadth of techniques utilized provides a long-term training benefit to the students carrying out the research. Tightly integrated with the research plan is an educational outreach program built around the development and dissemination of a set of unique and engaging teaching kits. Specific efforts are made to target diversity goals, largely by tapping into the extraordinarily diverse student community and existing educational outreach programs at Stony Brook University.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Perovskite oxides are ideal "building blocks" for artificial materials because within relatively similar crystal structures they possess an extraordinary variety of complex structural distortions and associated functional properties. The key materials of interest in this project are either ferroic (ferroelectric, ferromagnetic, or ferroelastic) or multiferroic (exhibiting the combination of two or more ferroic properties in the same material). Recently there have been some astonishing examples in oxide materials in which behavior markedly different from bulk material properties is achieved by careful control of the interfaces. The central concept of the research is to use interfacial interactions, along with strain and electrostatics, to construct new ferroic materials with properties that are scientifically appealing and technologically useful. In practical terms, this involves the construction of fine period superlattices composed of titanate and manganite perovskite oxides using an off-axis RF magnetron sputtering technique. X-ray diffraction (both lab and synchrotron based), atomic force microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and electrical techniques are then used to explore the fundamental physics of the artificial materials. Special emphasis is placed on phase transitions and phenomena related to domains. The wide variety of experimental techniques used in the project provides a team of graduate, undergraduate and high school students with hands-on experience with cutting-edge research techniques and facilities.

This grant is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE)'s Europe and Eurasia Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ferroelectrics  are an important class of functional materials where electrical properties are strongly coupled to their crystal structure. The most important of these properties is the spontaneous development of electric dipoles within the material, that tend to arrange themselves in to regions, called domains, where they are pointing in the same direction.  In this project, layers of different kinds of these materials, as thin as only a few atoms, were deposited one on top of another to build up a new artificial material called a superlattice. To learn about the properties of these materials, such as their polarization, responses to electrical and mechanical stimuli, and how the polarization domains are arranged, experimental probes that access the nanoscale are required. One powerful tool of this kind is x-ray diffraction using intense beams of x-rays provided by facilities such as the National Synchrotron Light Source and the new National Synchrotron Light Source – II at Brookhaven National Laboratory.  A major part of this project was to perform experiments at these facilities to amplify the results obtained in the main laboratory where this work was performed at Stony Brook University.  The lab at Stony Brook houses facilities for atomic force microscopy, electrical measurement and also x-ray diffraction, albeit with far less intense beams of radiation.

As part of the project new materials were designed that had enhanced properties. In one material an enhancement of piezoelectric response was achieved, and a combination of nanoscale characterization tools were used to show how and why this occurred and could be controlled.  In another, the interfaces in the material were assembled precisely enough that there was an intrinsic difference in the materials response to an electric field applied in one direction or the other.

It was realized as the project progressed that to really be able to full control the nature of ferroelectric superlattices, more information needed to be gained during the growth of these structures. Thus we developed a facility and methodology that enabled us to follow the structural evolution of growing superlattices using in-situ synchrotron x-ray diffraction at the NSLS and NSLS-II. Using this we uncovered important insights that will we enable more precise control of growth and the evolution of ferroelectricity during that growth. Besides this, the developments in infrastructure, methods and data handling capability will provide an invaluable tool for similar and not-so-similar research for years to come.

As we further developed our control over the surfaces of our samples and the arrangement of ferroelectric polarization within them we seized a unique opportunity to provide insight in to the process by which these materials can split water in to hydrogen under ultraviolet light. Using our specifically tailored surfaces to look at the earliest stages of this reaction with atomic force microscopy we discovered significant insights that could advance this important potential route to renewable energy storage. 

This project was performed primarily through the efforts of graduate students, three who have graduated with PhDs from Stony Brook and others who achieved Master’s degrees before moving on to PhD programs at other US institutions. In addition several high school students spent their summers in our laboratory, performed at the highest level in national science competitions and all have all gone on to study at some of the best universities in the country. As part of an effort to increase gender balance in the physical sciences the project is proud to report that about 50% of participants in the project were women. Besides the training our project provided, we were excited to develop a ferroelectric test  system that could be assembled at extremely low cost using commonly available parts, which could enable anyone to measure the ferroelectric properties of a material in an educational or hobbyist setting.
